fxInfo_label: Criteria for appointment decisions in the armed forces
fxInfo_citation: Pemstein et al. (2018, V-Dem Working Paper Series 2018:21); V-Dem Codebook (see suggested citation at the top of this document).
fxInfo_clarification: Appointment decisions include hiring, firing and promotions in the armed forces. Note that the question refers to the typical de facto (rather than de jure) situation obtaining in the armed forces. If there are large differences between different branches of the armed forces or between top and lower level ranks please try to consider the average when answering the question.
fxInfo_cross_coder_aggregation: Bayesian Item Response Theory Measurement Model
fxInfo_question: To what extent are appointment decisions in the armed forces based on personal or political connections or alternatively based on skills and merit?

fxInfo_responses.value: All appointment decisions in the armed forces are based on personal or political connections. None are based on skills and merit.
Most appointment decisions in the armed forces are based on personal or political connections. Only a few are based on skills and merit.
Approximately half of the appointment decisions in the armed forces are based on personal or political connections. Approximately half are based on skills and merit.
Only few of the appointment decisions in the armed forces are based on personal or political connections. Most are based on skills and merit.
None of the appointment decisions in the armed forces are based on personal or political connections. All are based on skills and merit.

fxInfo_scale: Ordinal, converted to interval by the measurement model
